definition: Zhou Shuren, the real name of author Lu Xun 魯迅|鲁迅
surname Zhou/Zhou Dynasty (1046-256 BC)
to make a circuit/to circle/circle/circumference/lap/cycle/complete/all/all over/thorough/to help financially
week/weekly/variant of 周[zhou1]
tree/CL:棵[ke1]/to cultivate/to set up
man/person/people/CL:個|个[ge4],位[wei4]
Lu Xun (1881-1936), one of the earliest and best-known modern Chinese writers

Zhou Zuoren (1885-1967), brother of Lu Xun 魯迅|鲁迅, academic in Japanese and Greek studies, briefly imprisoned after the war as Japanese collaborator, persecuted and died of unknown causes during the Cultural Revolution
Zhang Taiyan (1869-1936), scholar, journalist, revolutionary and leading intellectual around the time of the Xinhai revolution
Hu Shi (1891-1962), original proponent of writing in colloquial Chinese 白話文|白话文[bai2 hua4 wen2]
Cai Yuanpei (1868-1940), liberal educationalist, studied in Germany, president of Peking University 1917-19, minister of education for Guomindang
Chen Duxiu (1879-1942), co-founder of the Chinese Communist Party in 1921
Mao Dun (1896-1981), Chinese novelist
Yan Fu (1853-1921), influential Chinese writer and translator of Western books, esp. on social sciences
Shao Piaoping (1884-1926), pioneer of journalism and founder of newspaper Beijing Press 京報|京报, executed in 1926 by warlord Zhang Zuolin 張作霖|张作霖
Liang Qichao (1873-1929), influential journalist and a leader of the failed reform movement of 1898
Wen Yiduo (1899-1946), poet and patriotic fighter, executed by Guomindang in Kunming
courtesy name of Lin Shu 林紓|林纾[Lin2 Shu1]
Zhu Ziqing (1898-1948), poet and essayist
Zhang Taiyan 章太炎 (1869-1936), scholar, journalist, revolutionary and leading intellectual around the time of the Xinhai revolution
Xu Dishan (1893-1941), journalist, publisher and novelist
the New Culture Movement (mid-1910s and 1920s), intellectual revolution against Confucianism aiming to introduce Western elements, especially democracy and science
